ALBERT.raw_line: That's Mooney's colt!You bought him?No.No. No, please don't take him back.I'll train him.Please, Mum. Please let me. I can do it.Right. Let's make a start then.It's oats. Very tasty, that is. It's beef and gravy to us!Come on...I bet you're missing your mother. Look at you... first time without your mum. First time away from home. But you're not alone, are you. In fact. Cos I'm `ere...It's alright. It's alright.I'm gonna call you Joey. Understand? Joey. That's you. And I'm Albert. It's alright, You're mine now. You're mine.Whoa. I want you to stay there, Joey. Stay. That's it. Good boy. That's it, you've got it.Right, come on, Joey. Back you go. Come on. Back you go.You're all right. That's it. Good boy. Right. You've gotta stay there, understand?That's it. Good boy. You've got it. Good boy.Come now, Joey. Come on.You can come now, Joey.No, I read it in a story. It's how the Indians used to summon their horses. He gently strokes Joey's nose.Now, Joey, when I whistle, you've gotta come, understand?He's not a dog. He's just puzzling it through.What if he doesn't?No, please. Sir, you can't do that.You can't harness him.No, you can't. Look, you're scaring him, Dad. You're scaring him. He... He can't take a plow!He won't be able to do it - he's too young - he's not even been backed yet....It's alright, boy. It's alright. It's alright. It's alright.Dad? He grabs the rifle, but Dad shoves him away.Dad. Stop.You were right what you said, Dad. "He'll do it," you told Lyons, "He'll plow that field." And he will! You'll see. He'll show you. We'll show you. We'll get it done.How are you today, Joey? I don't know much about life, boy, but I do know that there are big days and there are small days. And most days are small days, and, well, they don't matter much to anyone - but this - well, this is a big one. This is our big day. Well, it's cold out there. So I'm going to take this off - Well, if it's tough for you - it should be tough for me, too...Now, I'm gonna teach you how to plow and you're gonna learn. Is that understood? And then we can be together, which is how I believe things are meant to be.Boy. Steady, boy. Here we go. Here we go.Easy, easy... Look at me, Joey. See? See? You've just gotta put your nose through.That's it. See? You've got it. You've got it. Good boy. There...See Joey - I got the collar, too!Come on, boy. Walk on. That's it. Walk on! Walk on, Joey. Come on, boy, walk on.Walk on, Joey! Walk on! Come on, Joey, walk on. Walk on, boy.Walk on. Come on, walk on.Good boy. Good lad. Good lad. Now walk on. Good boy.Do you know - I believe we can do it, Joey. I knew when I first saw you that you'd be the best of us. That's why he bought you. He knows you've all the courage he never had. I knew when I first saw you that you'd be the one who'd save us.Whoa. Whoa. Lyons calls from the crowd as rain starts to fall.Now, boy! You've got to do it, Joey. You don't know, so I'm gonna have to do the knowing for you when the rest of our lives depend on this! So get set to pull - and pull straight! And pull hard!Now, boy! Go!Walk on, Joey! Walk on! That's it! Good boy, Joey! Good boy!Whoa, Joey! Whoa, Joey! Joey! Joey, whoa whoa whoa! Joey, stop! You'll break the blade -And where's Dad?Stumbling about, I suppose.He drinks, mum.Well, he don't talk to me about it.Not dad's?I'd be proud. If I'd gone off to war. If I'd gone and saved my mates, and -Sergeant, Seventh Battalion, Imperial Yeomanry. You see this, Joey? It's been through an entire war.I'm not stealing it. I'll give it back to him, someday.Come on, boy, let's show her how to fly!Well...you're clearly not gonna be a jumper.We can try planting something else, or we could hire ourselves out to Uncle Bob.How else we gonna pay Mr. Lyons' rent?Look smart, Joey lad, it's the Tavistock Fair!What has he done with him?You can't! You can't, he's mine! I trained him!You can't have him. He's my horse, sir.Please, I'll get you money. I will, I'll get you money. I'll...I'll work for it! I'll work for it. He won't obey anyone else. He won't be any good in the war, neither. He...he shies at every sound!Well, if Joey's going, I'm going, too. I'm volunteering.Albert, sir.Nineteen, sir.No sir. But, but I look nineteen and I'm bigger than most nineteen-year- olds, sir! And I'm strong, sir! And I...I'm not afraid of anything.It's all right, boy...Joey...This isn't the end. This isn't the end, my brother... I, Albert Narracott, solemnly swear we will be together again. Wherever you are, I will find you. And I will bring you home!Well, who'd be sending me a parcel over there?It's a sketchbook... That's Captain Nicholls' sketchbook! See that? That's a picture of Joey!And there's a letter...All right. "Dear Albert Narracott.Captain Nicholls, who died...Captain Nicholls, who died in action today left you this. Yours, Sergeant Sam Perkins.He was riding Joey when he died."In action," it says.That's my business.Stay here.Remember that day me and Joey raced you in your car?Who was that girl you were with?There was. Don't you remember?You know what it reminds me of out there?That bloody impossible lower field the day me and Joey plowed it. Best day of my life that was and you were there.Stick close to the gentry, that's our ticket, yeah? We have the pluck but they have the luck. They both smile. And then the fear takes over again. Andrew particularly feels as though he is on the very edge now. David urges them forward.It's good. Andrew, it's good. Andrew! Nobody's retreating today. Andrew! Andrew! Nobody. Is retreating. Today.You'll be all right here. You'll be safe. Someone'll come for ya.It's all right. It's all right. We're Devon boys, yeah? David looks at Albert as though seeing him for the first time.We made it. We made it.Andrew, this way out! Suddenly ANOTHER SOLDIER leaps from a trench branch between them, shouting in panic.What is it?What kind of an horse?Miraculous horse...Joey?Hello, Joey. Hello boy. Where you been then, hey? Where in the world you been?Narracott, Private Albert Narracott, sir.He's not random at all, sir! He's my horse, I raised him, in Devon. Sir, look at his legs! He's got four white socks, he's brown all over - (points to his ownYou see, sir? He's not random at all.Thank you, sir.I don't understand, sir.Does the Major know?Sir, I'll give you all your money. Everything you paid when we get back to England. I'll give you twice -Oh, but you're wrong, sir, I know everything!Don't be worried, boy, when I go. I won't worry over you none. Hey, I found you, didn't I, and you found me.And we'll both... we'll both know that we made it through. Now go on.We're the lucky ones. Always have been. Lucky since the day I met you.God be with you, sir.It's my father's. It's his regimental pennant. How did you come by this, sir?Thank you ever so much for this, sir...What was her name?

EMILIE.raw_line: Grandpére.It's closer today.I can hear it, Grandpére, and there is no wind. You shouldn't lie to me.You lie about everything. You say you aren't worried but it's clear you are. I know the war is approaching but you say, "Oh, it's just a trick of the wind."You started lying when Mama and Papa went away.They're dead. But you won't say so. Do you think I'll die if you tell me the truth?If you tell me the truth about the war, I will tell you the truth about the big horses I've been keeping in the windmill.Yes. They were standing in the windmill waiting for Don Quixote. This is François and this is Claude .I named them after two boys who broke my heart last Summer.Yes - I know, Grandpére. They are not unicorns - so I will be fair and wait -- one day.And if no one comes to get them by night-time, then they belong to me.Mother used to tell me how my bones would give way with the slightest bump or fall.It will only be settled when I decide which one to ride first.At least I won't have long to wait.I was in love with a boy called François - who had your lovely eyes. Unfortunately he was in love with a girl called Marie, who had your teeth. She fell for a boy called Claude - who broke my heart. And who I intend to marry one day.Eyes on me. No talking.Today we learn to jump. Did you know the French cleared one meter eighty- five at the Paris Olympics to win the gold medal? Today we will beat that record.This is your jump. When I call you....be very brave and leap over it.Leap over it! Watch me.And now it's your --He doesn't think we can do it. But we will show him, won't we?No need to be afraid. (Emilie looking down at how far off the groundOnly if you get in my way to make me fall.What horses?We use it to replace the mattress stuffings.They're dead. They died.Tell me what happened to them. To my mother and father.You said you would tell me how they died. On my birthday. And tomorrow's my birthday! They died fighting, didn't they? But when the soldiers COME -- you do nothing. You are a coward, aren't you?And you've never done a brave thing in your life?I don't want to hear about the birds.What is that?I hope you have not bought me a disgusting dress that I then have to wear like last year.Yes. I looked like an ugly nun.Give me your hand. Grandpére, we have no money. When the war is over, then you can buy me jewels and carriages.Of course. Okay, I promise.I promise.My hero.No! Let go of me! No!You don't need them! There are so many others!François!

GRANDFATHER.raw_line: The wind plays tricks with the noise - it's moving away from us.Here. There is no wind here. But over there - a wind so strong it will lift you off the ground...Did I say that?The truth is - He feeds her a spoonful of the medicine.- you should speak to your elders with respect.Now - who is the one telling lies! EXT. COURTYARD. SAME.In the windmill?Yeah.They must belong to someone. Horses like this don't just appear from a fairy-tale.Emilie... Emilie...Emilie. Look at me. You cannot ride.Yes. That's right. So it is settled? She kisses his cheek --Good girl.But it's - Over my dead body!You'll kill yourself.Oh please, come off the ladd--Find somewhere to hide them. And do it quickly!!!My name is Bonnard - this is my land. Why are you here?They are taking everything. Where are the horses?Leave it if you don't know what it's for.I make jam. We have no animals.Yes.The wind. It plays tricks in the attic.An old house creaks. Go - close the shutters.If you or any of your friends harm her, as old as I am, I will kill you.Yes. Yes. It was your parents who were brave. I make jams.Maybe there are different ways to be brave. Did you know the French have the best carrier pigeons? And this could be the difference in the war - our messages getting through.They are released at the front and told to go home - this is all they know. But to get there they must fly over a war. Can you imagine such a thing? Here you are flying over so much pain and terror - and you know you can never look down. You have to look forward or you'll never get home. I ask you - what could be braver than that?A present.It was disgusting?Anything you say, my sweet one. Anything-you-say! You are, of course, the boss. It's just an old thing I found - don't worry yourself - leave it, I'll put it back. He leaves the room. Now Emilie is alone and she can't help it when she brings her eyes back to the object covered by the rug. She looks back over her shoulder to make sure she's not being watched and then lifts one corner of the rug. Her face explodes with a gorgeous smile. She pulls off the rug that is covering the big thing and...it is a gorgeous old saddle. She runs her hand along the saddle -- can hardly believe it.It was your mother's. I hid it, so as not to encourage you. Emilie, I want you to ride very slowly, very carefully. And promise me you won't go far --To the top of the hill and straight back again.Slowly...slowly...Emilie!Emilie!She is my granddaughter! Emilie, stop! Don't hurt her, please! Don't hurt her.Please, take the bigger one and leave the smaller one. You are breaking my granddaughter's heart.What will happen to them?It will never be over!And sir, if you bid against me, I will sell the coat on my back and bid to one hundred and ten. And if you bid against me again, I will sell my farm and bid to a thousand.You don't know anything about him.Yes, you found him! I heard you found a horse in the wire between the armies -When I heard about the miracle horse, I traveled three days because I knew whose horse it was. My granddaughter's. She saved his life! He was everything to her.The war has taken everything from everyone. He is all that I have left of her.Do you know what this is?You may have this.... And this.No no, not necessary. He belongs to you. That is, of course, what my little girl would have wanted. And she was the boss.Emilie. Her name is Emilie.

I'm just after tending to this here horse, is all!The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want, he leadeth me into green pastures, he lay me down beside the still waters...Poor beastie. Poor babbie. It's alright. It's alright. Don't buck and wriggle so, you're only shredding yourself.You'll blind yourself.Bugger me worthless - I didn't think to bring gloves or something to cut THE -OW! DAMN! OW!!Yeah, yeah I... Ummm, thanks. Cheers. Cheers...Thanks.You speak good English.Pity you didn't bring a second pair. Then I could cut the wire here -Say no more, I'm right behind you.And you understand what's happening, do you not, O Best Beloved? That you must lay so very nice and still. There's a lad, you're a remarkable horse, you are, helping us help you. There's a lad. There's a remarkable lad.So how's things in yonder trench?Well, if ever you need any more rats, we can always send ours over. `Cause we've more than we need, strictly speaking. Besides, they scare off all the pretty girls.Big strapping German girls, eh? Kind what gives robust massages?Look at that horse! Look at the muscles he's got, them long legs. They're made for running, horses. Runnin' away from danger.Yet we taught `em opposite. Running into the fray.Yeah. War horse. And there he is. What a strange beast you've become.I take him back with me, yeah?In a pig's eye. He's English, plain to see.Because he's so smart. And you're none too clean yourself.No, thanks, pet. Must be careful not to start a war. Do you have a coin of any sort?Yeah. He takes a coin from his pocket, hands it to the Geordie, who looks at it.All right, Fritz - you're on.Peter - I'm Colin.Heads. Peter spins it in the air and lets it fall into the mud. They look down. Peter shakes his head, resigned.Gone quiet, hasn't it?I'm a terrible shot, Pete, don't believe I'll ever hit the target.I will.And you take care of your own strange self.Thanks.I'll use `em back in the garden in South Shields. You can't see `cause of the mud.Four white socks!We've all clubbed together. It's everything we have. There's twenty-nine pounds there. Buy him back.The Major put in ten.Mum's the word where the Major's concerned. Your friend on the crutches over there -- even asked the Major to say that Joey was his, an officer's horse, so that he could go back with the others.You're alright. Nobody's gonna bid more than fifteen for a thoroughbred. They want work horses.No, I found him, he raised him -Where is your granddaughter?
